content.question: All coordinates are approximate. Moving from left to right: The curve begins at point (0 comma 0). The curve trends up gradually then levels to reach its maximum point at (1 comma 1). At point (1 comma 1), the curve trends down gradually, crossing the x axis at (2 comma 0), continues down gradually then levels to reach its minimum point at (3 comma negative 1). At point (3 comma negative 1), the curve trends up gradually to the right and ends at point (4 comma 0). ​The graph of the sinusoidal function <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is given in the <math alttext="x y"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>-plane. What is the length of the largest interval of input values of <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> on which an inverse function of <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> can be constructed?

choices.label: ​There is no interval larger than a single point on which <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is invertible.
